SECTION IV: Recovery Teams Procedures
This section is designed for use by the CPR, BFT members and their delegates, or other key stakeholders to determine if the severity of the incident warrants a Business Continuity Plan activation.
The On-call CPR Lead identifies whether a Business Continuity (BC) incident should be reported to the Business Function Team (BFT).
If a BCP activation is warranted, the CPR team should use the “Pre-Escalation Action Items” checklist below to initiate crisis communication with the BFT.
Contact and Convene the BFT
CPR team will assess the impact and pages out the BFT (ce-bft-epage) to begin crisis communication. As members of the BFT are contacted, they will be requested to:
Start or join a WebEx meeting (if available): https://cisco.webex.com/cisco
If Webex is not available, the following Everbridge Dial-In-Bridge can be activated:
Hosting a call:
To invite participants to your conference call, provide them with the Everbridge Dial-In Number and the Conference ID and passcode number:
Dial-In Number
Conference ID #: Passcode
If Everbridge Dial-In Bridge cannot be activated, CPR Lead uses mobile phone to organize BFT briefing with appropriate and available BFT Members

Form a BFT Command Center and Action Plan Once BFT members have been contacted to form a command center via WebEx and/or other bridge line, the following items should be discussed to initiate crisis communications and resume operations.
In case of a pandemic alert (WHO Phase 4+), the Cisco Global Pandemic Coordinator will convene BC teams for pandemic monitoring and response.
Execute the BFT Action Plan Once the BFT has determined a BCP activation is required, execute the following:
CPR Lead assumes responsibility.
Assign personnel as needed
Communicate with vendors as required
Act as a decision maker in the allocation of resources during the plan execution period
Keep the BFT informed as necessary and recommend a course of action
Ensure all continuity tasks are appropriately executed
Implement the appropriate business continuity strategies
Return to Normal Operations Once the BFT has determined the BCP can be deactivated, execute the following:
Identify and coordinate requirements to transition back to normal operations
Ensure business function restoration is successful
Inform all required stakeholders of restoration process (business unit, vendors, suppliers, etc.)
Provide return to normal communication to required stakeholders as outlined below

bft_cft_content.text: Recovery Strategies

The following tables below outlines the workaround and return to normal procedures for each all-hazards approach (technology outage, building/location unavailability, equipment unavailability, and supplier/vendor unavailability).
Appendix A – Recovery Scenarios & Processes

Fill out the section below for all potential scenarios (4 examples below) for which your Business Process can be impacted. Separate into different sections for scenarios where remediation steps are not the same.
Scenario Types:
Natural Disaster (Earthquake, Tornado, Flooding, anything applicable to your geographical location, etc.)
Technological (Network outage, DNS outage, communications outage, critical application outage etc.)
Human/Community Impact (Pandemic, War, etc.)
Cyber Attack (Critical application hacked for your business process and data stolen)
Summary of incident: Briefly describe the incident. Incidents can vary and range from personnel, technology, natural disasters, cyber-attacks, etc.

Remediation Steps: Describe each step in as much detail as would be necessary for someone unfamiliar with the system (but technically capable) to follow and complete the remediation. Contact the appropriate stakeholders (recovery teams) and provide crisis communications as necessary. Utilize workaround strategies until service/facility/technology/etc. resumes.

Technologies utilized for the remediation process: List applications, scripts, systems necessary to complete the remediation steps. Standard Cisco applications and several other critical tools such as CSOne and other apps with their respective recovery strategies listed above.

Personnel Skills Required: Describe the number of personnel and specific skills essential for the remediation steps above. Customer Service, Cisco Equipment Experience, diploma or technical background.

Post remediation monitoring: Describe any logs, dashboards, etc. that should be monitored post-remediation to ensure stability of the recovered system(s). Any offline or manual work should be reconciled as appropriate. Continue to monitor for any further potential issues that may arise.

Post resolution procedures: Describe additional tasks/procedures that should be completed post resolution such as bug reports, configuration changes, change request updates, other potential system failures, etc. Notes may need to be recorded into the appropriate platform. See resumption procedures for applications.
This is an offline directory for use to contact teams should the online directory not be available.

data: Command Center for Cisco Managed Services: Remote Monitor/Manage Customer Networks (NOC)

IT event coordination (Scheduled and Unscheduled services outages); Event Duty Manager for CMS (BCP activation, coordination); CMS Duty Manager (non-BCP); Catastrophic outage on managed services platform

Governance of change activities in the customer network. Interfaces closely with customer's change management team. BAC process is more rigorous, and they rely on our processes more than other customers.

The Cisco Managed Services (CMS) PM executes the ITIL v3 components of PM, supporting the following activities within the scope of Service Delivery: Manage the life cycle of all problems from identification to removal. Understand, document and communicate root cause and known errors and initiate actions to improve or advise on the correction to business and technical situations that promote them. Reactively minimize the adverse impacts of incidents and problems. Proactively prevent recurrence of incidents related to errors. Advise on calibration and optimization of service delivery monitoring tools.

CMS Access Management process provides a mechanism to manage certain privileges to Cisco employees, authorized by a customer. The process outlines the various types of Cisco roles and the corresponding level of access and privilege Cisco personnel need, to access customer network and to execute their roles in the services.

Most users are setup to work remotely. Transition Workload Working from home may not be feasible in all situations. If CX CMS is unable to operate at normal productivity levels by working at home, then the BFT/Event Duty Manager may decide to offload work to the shift before and the shift after the affected site. To get that help, the Command Center Duty Manager works with the Local Site Contacts, and the BFT Managers to allocate the workload to non-impacted sites. • Identify dependencies on potential site • Identify additional workload on potential site • Coordinate transition with appropriate teams and management Relocate Personnel to Alternate Site If a CX CMS site is unavailable for an extended period, the BFT will decide alternatives, such as temporarily working in another building or moving to a different site until the original site is accessible again. The Site Manager will communicate the instructions and timing of moving to a different building or site location once that location becomes available. • Identify Site • Coordinate Relocation Requirements • Inform Employees of Site Move and Schedule

Business Function Team (BFT)
The BFT coordinates all continuity activities and controls the implementation of the plan.
If ePage is down, utilize the following workarounds
Cisco e-page: bft-cxc-americas@epage.cisco.com / bft-cxc-emear@epage.cisco.com / bft-cxc-apjc@epage.cisco.com
Cross-Functional Team (CFT) - Optional
The CFT offers extended response to other functional or physical locations, as needed.
SECTION IV: Recovery Teams Procedures
This section is designed for use by CPR and BFT members and their delegates, or other key stakeholders to determine if the severity of the incident warrants a Business Continuity Plan activation.
If a BCP activation is warranted, the CPR team should use the “Pre-Escalation Action Items” checklist below to initiate crisis communication with the BFT.
Contact and Convene the BFT
CPR team will assess the impact and pages out the BFT to begin crisis communication. As members of the BFT are contacted, they will be requested to:

Form a BFT Command Center and Action Plan Once BFT members have been contacted to form a command center via WebEx and/or other bridge line, the following items should be discussed to initiate crisis communications and resume operations.
Execute the BFT Action Plan Once the BFT has determined a BCP activation is required, execute the following:
Keep the BFT informed as necessary and recommend a course of action
Return to Normal Operations Once the BFT has determined the BCP can be deactivated, execute the following:
SECTION V: Recovery Strategies- Business Critical

bft_cft_content.text: Recovery Strategies

The following tables below outlines the workaround and return to normal procedures for each all-hazards approach (technology outage, building/location unavailability, equipment unavailability, and supplier/vendor unavailability).

Remediation Steps: Describe each step in as much detail as would be necessary for someone unfamiliar with the system (but technically capable) to follow and complete the remediation. Contact the appropriate stakeholders (recovery teams) and provide crisis communications as necessary. Utilize workaround strategies until service/facility/technology/etc. resumes.

Instructions for use: The BFT should discuss if customer communications are necessary with current or expected circumstances, and nominate one individual to prepare and modify these templates for distribution to customers. Existing CMS tools may provide a method of managing these email communications.

CXLT is a global CX LABS tool for case and inventory management. ​ CX Lab Tool (CXLT) is the new single CX Labs Tool that will, over time, integrate the functions that currently are supported in Lions, CloudForms, AutoPods, and NetSim.​
Lions is a global CX Labs tool for tracking Professional Services (Proactive) and SVS lab engagements.

ManageIQ is an open-source cloud management platform deployed in several CX Labs regions around the globe. A ManageIQ outage in a region will prevent users of that site from being able to create or modify virtual machines​ ​
OmniTool/ OT6 : is a global CX Labs tool for tracking Technical Services (Reactive) lab engagements used by TAC engineers.​ ​

data: Problem resolution and solution development recreated in a lab environment to resolve customer issues and/or validate bug related issues for the CX Engineering community. Labs are configured by the CX Engineers. Includes lab gear for infrastructure and customer recreates. Equipment comes into lab (not shipping directly to customer). Virtual Machine slots are made available to persons in the CX Engineering community requiring virtual environments.

Engineers often need to request lab recreates based off of customer migration plans or integration. Engineers use the lab to validate code, create MOP, or verify configuration changes and are responsible for the customer confidentiality.
Maintain enduring labs (long term customer labs), which are solution specific and used for testing upgrades and problem resolution for customers for one or more years.

On-Call Duty Manager (DM)
https://cxlabs-docs.cisco.com/doku.php?id=external:support:support_hours
On-Call CPR Team
CPR- CLIP Instance ( If CLIP is unavailable, go to step 2)
CXC CPR Team On-Call (VPN needed, if unavailable CPR contact information is listed in the BFT)
Business Function Team (BFT)
The BFT coordinates all continuity activities and controls the implementation of the plan.
Cisco Mailer: cx-labs-bcp@cisco.com
If e-Page is down, utilize the following workarounds
Cross-Functional Team (CFT) - Optional
The CFT offers extended response to other functional or physical locations, as needed.
SECTION IV: Recovery Teams Procedures
This section is designed for use by the CPR, BFT members and their delegates, or other key stakeholders to determine if the severity of the incident warrants a Business Continuity Plan activation.
If a BCP activation is warranted, the CPR team should use the “Pre-Escalation Action Items” checklist below to initiate crisis communication with the BFT.
Contact and Convene the BFT
CPR team will assess the impact and pages out the BFT to begin crisis communication. As members of the BFT are contacted, they will be requested to:

Form a BFT Command Center and Action Plan Once BFT members have been contacted to form a command center via WebEx and/or other bridge line, the following items should be discussed to initiate crisis communications and resume operations.
Execute the BFT Action Plan Once the BFT has determined a BCP activation is required, execute the following:
Keep the BFT informed as necessary and recommend a course of action
Return to Normal Operations Once the BFT has determined the BCP can be deactivated, execute the following:

The following tables below outlines the workaround and return to normal procedures for each all-hazards approach (technology outage, building/location unavailability, equipment unavailability, and supplier/vendor unavailability).

Remediation Steps: Describe each step in as much detail as would be necessary for someone unfamiliar with the system (but technically capable) to follow and complete the remediation. Contact the appropriate stakeholders (recovery teams) and provide crisis communications as necessary. Utilize workaround strategies until service/facility/technology/etc. resumes.

On-Call CPR Team

CXC CPR Team On-Call (VPN needed, if unavailable CPR contact information is listed with the BFT)
Business Function Team (BFT)
The BFT coordinates all continuity activities and controls the implementation of the plan. ePage: cxc-ps-globalbft
Cross-Functional Team (CFT) - Optional
The CFT offers extended response to other functional or physical locations, as needed.
SECTION IV: Recovery Teams Procedures
This section is designed for use by the CPR, BFT members and their delegates, or other key stakeholders to determine if the severity of the incident warrants a Business Continuity Plan activation.
If a BCP activation is warranted, the CPR team should use the “Pre-Escalation Action Items” checklist below to initiate crisis communication with the BFT.
Contact and Convene the BFT
CPR team will assess the impact and pages out the BFT to begin crisis communication. As members of the BFT are contacted, they will be requested to:
The following additional resource(s) can be used to convene the BFT:
ePage: cxc-ps-globalbft

Form a BFT Command Center and Action Plan Once BFT members have been contacted to form a command center via WebEx and/or other bridge line, the following items should be discussed to initiate crisis communications and resume operations.
Execute the BFT Action Plan Once the BFT has determined a BCP activation is required, execute the following:
Keep the BFT informed as necessary and recommend a course of action
Return to Normal Operations Once the BFT has determined the BCP can be deactivated, execute the following:
SECTION V: Recovery Strategies – Business Critical

Recovery Strategies

The following tables below outlines the workaround and return to normal procedures for each all-hazards approach (technology outage, building/location unavailability, equipment unavailability, and supplier/vendor unavailability).
Remediation Steps: Contact the appropriate stakeholders (recovery teams) and provide crisis communications as necessary. Utilize workaround strategies until service/facility/technology/etc. resumes.

SECTION IV: Recovery Teams Procedures
This section is designed for use by the CPR, BFT members and their delegates, or other key stakeholders to determine if the severity of the incident warrants a Business Continuity Plan activation.
If a BCP activation is warranted, the CPR team should use the “Pre-Escalation Action Items” checklist below to initiate crisis communication with the BFT.
Contact and Convene the BFT Once the DM has determined the incident must be escalated i.e the DM should contact the CPR team.
CPR team will assess the impact and pages out the BFT to begin crisis communication. As members of the BFT are contacted, they will be requested to:

Form a BFT Command Center and Action Plan Once BFT members have been contacted to form a command center via WebEx and/or other bridge line, the following items should be discussed to initiate crisis communications and resume operations.
Execute the BFT Action Plan Once the BFT has determined a BCP activation is required, execute the following:
Keep the BFT informed as necessary and recommend a course of action
Return to Normal Operations Once the BFT has determined the BCP can be deactivated, execute the following:
SECTION V: Recovery Strategies- Business Critical

bft_cft_content.text: SECTION VII: Recovery Strategies

The following tables below outlines the workaround and return to normal procedures for each all-hazards approach (technology outage, building/location unavailability, equipment unavailability, and supplier/vendor unavailability).

Remediation Steps: Describe each step in as much detail as would be necessary for someone unfamiliar with the system (but technically capable) to follow and complete the remediation. Contact the appropriate stakeholders (recovery teams) and provide crisis communications as necessary. Utilize workaround strategies until service/facility/technology/etc. resumes.

If labs in the affected site are unusable, Support Services engineers in the affected location will need to remotely use the labs in other locations. This is a limited workaround as labs must be physically accessed to perform certain tasks in service requests. Support Services can engage other sites to assist and/or assume ownership of such tasks/service requests. If resources are damaged (e.g. equipment, laptop), the manager closest to the information on what is needed will be tasked with replacement. For example, the site director may need to coordinate replacement of laptops, phones, etc. were affected by an event at a site. Most L1 TCE’s (GDP/Partner) do not have CVO (Cisco Virtual Office) or a company provided laptop. BFT/CXC CPR will contact the Support Services L1 Vendor Managers for options such as VPN. Support Services engineers can normally work from home by connecting to VPN (AnyConnect) or CVO (Cisco Virtual Office setup) to work service requests. However, working from home may not be feasible in all situations & if Support Services is unable to operate at normal productivity levels by working at home, then the BFT/CXC CPR may decide to offload Service Requests to other available teams/theaters. In that event, the BFT/CXC CPR will work with Routing Ops to change case routing to other theatres for technology queues, and in some situations, it may be necessary to assign existing Service Requests to those other Support Services sites. GDP/Partner Vendors, Managers and other necessary teams may be utilized as well. The Support Services Technology Team Manager (not the CPR/DM) continues to be responsible for assigning existing Service Requests to other Support Services sites. They will Identify dependencies on potential site, identify additional workload on potential site and help coordinate transition with appropriate teams and management. Additionally, some locations such as Bangalore do not have WFH capabilities and may need to use tethering via mobile phones, procure extra equipment or make other arrangements determined by the BFT/CXC CPR team. If a Support Services site is unavailable for an extended period, the BFT will decide alternatives, such as temporarily working in another building or moving to a different site until the original site is accessible again. Your local CSC (Cisco Security Center) can be engaged to help allocate workspaces. The Site Director or Theater VP will communicate the instructions and timing of moving to a different building or site location once that location becomes available. Sydney for example can re-locate to Sydney Office Level-22 if needed. Bangalore for example can re-locate to BGL13 if needed. All other centers re-locations will be determined by BFT/CXC CPR/Site Directors.

CXC CPR/CXC DM is responsible for monitoring the status of the efforts to restore functionality and to ensure regular communications to Worldwide CX Centers and its leadership until all services/operations are return to normal. Once services have been restored and return to full capacity, CXC CPR/CXC DM will coordinate with Routing Ops team and necessary teams to revert any changes made during outage. The CXC CPR/CXC DM will help assist in communicating the need to return cases to proper theaters/teams, transfer workloads, and resume normal operations.

bft_cft_content.text: BFT: Business Function Team (Primary Contacts to be Alerted)
SECTION IV: Recovery Teams
On-Call Duty Manager (DM)
On-Call Duty Manager Schedule (VPN needed)
On-Call CPR Team
CPR Team Incident Open and Epage (If NaaS E-Page or CLIP unavailable, go to step 2)
CXC CPR Team On-Call (VPN needed, if unavailable CPR contact information is listed with the BFT)
Business Function Team (BFT)
The BFT coordinates all continuity activities and controls the implementation of the plan.
Cisco e-page: tac-bft (Link to NaaS [E-Page])
If ePage is down (or recipient is not using NaaS), utilize the following workarounds
Cross-Functional Team (CFT) - Optional
The CFT offers extended response to other functional or physical locations, as needed.
SECTION V: Recovery Teams Procedures
This section is designed for use by the CPR, BFT members and their delegates, or other key stakeholders to determine if the severity of the incident warrants a Business Continuity Plan activation.
If a BCP activation is warranted, the CPR team should use the “Pre-Escalation Action Items” checklist below to initiate crisis communication with the BFT.
Contact and Convene the BFT The DM should contact the CPR team to begin crisis communications via an incident report. As members of the BFT are contacted, they will be requested to:
Form a BFT Command Center and Action Plan
Once BFT members have been contacted to form a command center via Webex and/or other bridge line, the following items should be discussed to initiate crisis communications and resume operations.
Execute the BFT Action Plan Once the BFT has determined a BCP activation is required, execute the following:
Keep the BFT informed as necessary and recommend a course of action
Return to Normal Operations Once the BFT has determined the BCP can be deactivated, execute the following:
SECTION III: Business Process Scope and Recovery Timeframes (RTO)
